I was running out of room on my desk, and couldn't fit my keyboard under my monitor stand. I could have purchased one that worked better, but hey, I have a 3D printer. So, I designed this monitor stand so you can make one that fits you needs.
I've included a set of STL files that you can print as is, or you can use the OpenSCAD files to customize the design to meet your needs.

The design used 3/4 inch square aluminum tube I purchased from my local home improvement store. You could use steel instead if you want. For my stand, I cut two pieces that were 2 feet long each. I cut these from a single 6-foot piece I purchased using a hacksaw.

You should be able to print the four supports (Vertical_Support.stl). These allow about 65mm of vertical clearance for your keyboard, and should push onto the ends of the square tube.  
The horizontal supports (Horizontal_Support.stl) is rather large, at 250 mm along it's longest dimension. If your print bed is smaller than that, try rotating it so it prints diagonally on your printer.

If you want to use different sized parts, use the OpenSCAD files. The Horizontal_Support.scad file creates the platforms that hold the monitor. The Width controls the front-to-back flat dimension on these parts. Height is how wide these supports will be. And Thickness is the thickness of the flat areas between the front and back. Finally, tubeWidth is the size of the square tube, so you can change the parts to work with tubes of a different size.  
The posts are customized using Post.scad, and only has two values. You use tubeWidth to set the size of the square tube. And use clearance to set the height of the opening. I used 65mm for this as I have a rather tall keyboard.

title: Viewfinder for P6*6 / P6*6W Pinhole Cameras

description.text:
Be deliberate! Be strategic!  Knowing the boundaries of your scene is vital to compositional and artistic control. These viewfinders straddle the body clip and give an accurate angular guide to composition. Keep in mind, for very close subjects, parallax effects will become significant.   
These can be used as is, but they are designed to temporarily snap together, mated with either a short length of 3mm filament, or 3mm rare Earth magnets, which will hold the VF in place - even inverted.

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license. with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design.

These should be robust parts, print with 0.25mm layer height for accuracy and 2 perimeters/50% infill for strength.   
A 6mm length of 3.00 mm filament can be used to peg these parts together (glue only in the top of the body clip) or 3mm rare Earth magnets can be employed to hold them together.   
The holes are a nominal 3mm, but may need some enlarging with an appropriately-sized drill bit. The 3mm magnets I used are precisely 3mm; an 1/8 inch drill bit is approx 3.15mm. I used the next smaller size, 7/64ths and slightly enlarged the holes.  If you're using superglue, you have essentially one shot to get the magnet seated completely in the hole.

comments.text:
That's a very good addition to the pinhole P66 :)
May I ask you how you have designed its dimensions ?
My baby bessa doesn't have a view finder ....and I was tempted to builld one !
comments.author: Lyscanthrope

comments.text:
If you know your "focal length" and frame length and width, then you have the dimensions of a pyramid that corresponds to the cone of light that exposes your film. Flipping the pyramid 180 degrees, gives you the vertical and horizontal angles of view into the camera. I shrink or enlarge [edit: SCALE] the pyramid as needed and that gives me the inside dimensions and angles of the view finder. For very close work, there will obviously be some parallax.
My terraPin designs have no viewfinders, but I want to make a WYSIWYG finder that swaps out of the tripod mount. Stay tuned.
T

The Rabbit H1 is a replacement for a computer mouse based on the human interface concept of aircraft throttles. It requires very little hand motion, as the fingers and thumb do all the work - your hand lays motionless on the device.
Move the cursor with the thumb joystick, the index finger controls left click and "mousewheel" actions, and the middle and ring fingers to middle and right click.
The electronics are based on the Teensy 2.0 dev board (http://www.pjrc.com/teensy) and will work on PC or Mac. Source file for the firmware is included here (h1_fw.ino).
Details on the build are here: http://davenunez.wordpress.com/2014/07/03/building-the-rabbit-h1-controller/

title: Printrbot Z-X Carriage Upgrade Leadscrew Support "Wings" Rev. E1

description.text:
Hi,  
This is yet another revision of this design but it has been modified so that you can attach the dumpstercnc (www.dumpstercnc.com) Delrin lead nuts with anti backlash springs, or the standard flange nuts.  
The screw pattern is for the 3/8-12 1 start nut flange. I believe any others have a different flange size. You could just modify the drawing if you wanted to use other sizes.  
I should note, my setup has this - "Add a .860" (21.8mm) machined cutdown flange with (2) .173" (4.4mm) dia holes." on the flange, which makes attachment a bit easier. This was available from dumpstercnc  
Like the previous revisions, It's designed to take advantage of the aluminium blocks on this carriage to bolt into, making a much firmer attachment. Stock, PB recommend you bolt the leadscrew supports into plywood holes on the carriage, which strip easily and flex a lot, causing banding.

comments.text: Thanks heaps!
comments.author: VintageTimeAustralia

comments.text: I printed these guys and ordered those anti backlash dohickeys in preparation for my z-x upgrade install. Really nice, efficient design. If I actually pull the trigger on going all aluminum (sent the dxf for both the Plus 2.1 and 2014 in for quotes on lasering 6mm aluminum) I'll surely post lots of pics with your part in 'em. Thanks for the great design!

description.text: The life of a garden gnome isn't exactly a bed of roses. Actually...that is exactly what it is. Unfortunately, young Gnorbert has just made the acquaintance of a few too many thorns. Update: Gnorbert V2 is an improved version with an explicit boundary for the horns and with improved geometry for better slicing. The provided V2 model is around 2.25 inches high, but it should print well at any size. Old version: The base model is "gnorbert.stl" and is stable enough that (at say 3-5 inches) he'd make a great holder for pens, votive candles, SD cards, etc. "gnorbert-hollow.stl" has a tube running up in the middle which makes it easier to get a good print without any in-fill, but he'd be harder to remix.

author: stocktonrgs

title: Printrbot Z-X Carriage Upgrade Leadscrew Support "Wings" Rev. E0

description.text:
This is yet another revision of this design but it has been modified so that you can choose between 3/18-12 or 1/4-16 ACME leadcrew lead nuts.  
The printed lead nuts actually work really well. I've tried them in both PLA and PET and really can't complain. They eliminated my backlash issues due to a much better fit than the standard supplied metal nuts, which had a fair bit of slop. Not to mention the thread just glides though them.  
Like the previous revisions, It's designed to take advantage of the aluminium blocks on this carriage to bolt into, making a much firmer attachment. Stock, PB recommend you bolt the leadscrew supports into plywood holes on the carriage, which strip easily and flex a lot, causing banding.

  • Glue the dividers together.

  • Set the dividers into the enclosure.
    • (optional) 5. Drill holes and attach a hinge, and secure the cover.

title: A lame duck with his 3d printed walking brace @ NTUVH

description.text:
Blog http://goo.gl/uFDoks
video http://youtu.be/gWyWU6PAl4g
FB http://goo.gl/HVAsCL
== 3D Printed walking brace for duck ==
Quack-Quack is a duck attacked by dogs on campus at NTU, Taiwan.
After surgery in NTUVH, it seemed like his left leg had slightly internal metatarsus torsion. For this reason, he used only right leg to bear almost all his weight for a while. Therefore, we designed a customized walking brace by using 3d scan and 3d printing techniques to avoid the stress of weight bearing on one leg, and to help him keeping his body in balance.
This video is to document the process from prototypes to the latest 3d printed part of duck's walking brace.
|
| http://goo.gl/uFDoks

description.text: My family has taken to playing pig, so I decided to create a tiny trophy that we could award daily. I cannot take credit for any of the pieces that were used, but I would like to compliment them all.
The technique I used to build it was to simply import all three pieces into Makerware and then align them as I wished. A little bit of scaling and I had exactly the result I was shooting for.

The better (1 arc second version) of Mount Fuji is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:725247 This version of Mount Fuji, 3 arc seconds in resolution, is constructed with SRTM2STL using SRTM data from the Space Shuttle. The source code for creating these files is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.
The picture shows a print I just did when posting this. It delaminated a bit. The other prints look much better. I'll post a better picture later.

comments.text: I was thinking about trying rigid connectors for tetrahedral kites. If you were to design a 9-way and a 12-way connector (with the proper angles of course) in addition to your 3- and 6-way connectors you could build a tetrahedral celled kite with any number of cells. My original plans (available for free at http://tetralite.comhttp://tetralite.com), use pieces of thin-wall PVC tubing held together with small electronics-type tie wraps to make the connectors. This method makes the connectors flexible, and by unplugging one end of each cell's "spreader" stick you can collapse the kite flat for storage and transportation. The largest kite I made using my method is 110 cells! See pictures and complete details on the http://tetralite.comtetralite.com website. If connectors were printed with flexible PLA perhaps they would be flexible enough to make a collapsible kite(?) -- I have yet to buy any flexible PLA, otherwise I'd try it.

description.text:
DIY material testing machine Inspired by some profesional tesing videos like ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tpGhqQvftAo ) I was thinking it should be possible to create something simmilar for testing 3D printed material. I have a very simple goal, mainly interested in relative strength between multiple test pieces. Like to be able to answer f.e. which print temperature gives the best connection between layers. More info and results;
http://umforum.ultimaker.com/index.php?/topic/6117-diy-material-testing-machine/

The swing is a simple piece of tube, with a piece of iron to cut through the test material. The swing is hanging in 2 bearings. The pointing mechanism is a very simple design, i think the rubberband idea needs some improvement...

author: UltiArjan

description.text: I recently created some gears for my Ultimaker. These spur gears are created especially for laser cutting. Prefered material is POM (delrin). They work perfectly as seen in the video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AAAizfJgaWM there's nearly no backlash at all. I was actually really surprised how well they worked. The hex nut can be pushed in with some force. This little gear is made for a non-D-shaped shaft motor and should also be placed by force. I cutted them in 3mm thick Delrin but 5mm should probably better.

title: The Celestial Sphere - 200 Brightest Stars - Star Projector

description.text: This thing allows you to print out the Celestial Sphere with small pentagonal holes drilled for each star. It has a hole in the South Pole, so if you put a bright point-source light such as an ultra-bright LED inside it, it acts as a simple star projector.

What is the Celestial Sphere? According to Wikipedia: "In astronomy and navigation, the celestial sphere is an imaginary sphere of arbitrarily large radius, concentric with the observer. All objects in the observer's sky can be thought of as projected upon the inside surface of the celestial sphere, as if it were the underside of a dome or a hemispherical screen. The celestial sphere is a practical tool for spherical astronomy, allowing observers to plot positions of objects in the sky when their distances are unknown or unimportant." If you look up into the night sky, you can imagine that the stars are projected onto the inside of a sphere that surrounds the earth. This is the Celestial Sphere. As the Earth spins around it's North/South axis every 24 hours, so the stars appear to rotate around the North and South Poles. Another way of looking at this, is that you can imagine the Earth being stationary and the Celestial Sphere rotating around the Earth once every 24 hours. Build instructions Print out the file 01CelestialSphere.stl. This is quite a long print because I have made the walls of the sphere 5mm thick in order to make it opaque. You can probably take this down to 2 or 3mm if you want. My Cura settings are in settings01.jpg and settings02.jpg. This is quite a technical print. There are three problems: 1) The sphere has to be large enough to adequately separate all of the stars. For example, if you make the sphere much smaller than the dimensions I have used, the stars in Orion's Belt all munge together far too much. If that's OK with you - go ahead - make it smaller. 2) The holes for the stars have to be large enough to be resolved by your printer. For me, I can't make the stars smaller than about 1mm radius or they loose all definition. 3) Printing hollow spheres can be difficult. As the curvature of the sphere flattens towards the horizontal, the print can fail. This is why I have made the walls so thick. The science bit The positions of the stars are recorded in star almanacs by right ascension (ra) and declination (dec). I have used the data from Wolfram Alpha (see the CelestialSphere.nb Mathematica notebook). The ra measures how far a star is in its "orbit" around the Earth's North Pole. It is given in decimal hours. This is because as the Earth rotates over a 24 hour period, the positions of the stars sweep 360 degrees around the Poles. So the rotation of the stars from some defined starting point can be expressed both as a time in hours and as an angle in degrees. A corollary of this is that if a telescope wishes to track a star, then it must rotate at a rate of 360/24 = 15 degrees per hour in the same plane of rotation as the stars. There are 24 facets on the printed sphere, so each facet is 1 hour or 15 degrees. Declination is the distance of the star above the plane of the ecliptic. The ecliptic is the plane in which the Earth and all other planets in the solar system orbit around the Sun. You can convert ra and dec to rotations about the Y and Z axis as follows: zrot = ra * 360/24
yrot = 90 - dec Given this information, modelling the Celestial Sphere is very easy: Draw a sphere radius r. // The Celestial Sphere
For each star
Draw a cylinder at the origin with axis along the Z axis
Rotate the cylinder first by yrot then by zrot
Project the cylinder out from the origin until it pierces the sphere. That's it! The tinkering bit You need the OpenSCAD files: 1) stars.scad - the 500 brightest stars in Cartesian and Polar coordinates.
2) 01CelestialSpherePolar.scad - the Celestial Sphere with a hole in the South Pole for a LED. If you want to tinker with the OpenSCAD files (and I hope you do!) please be aware that OpenSCAD takes an age to render all the stars. For 200 pentagonal stars, I had to leave it chundering away for a several hours on my 2011 MacBook Air. Ideally, I would like to print 500 stars, but life is too short. Also, I was going to make the stars the shape of Koch Snowflakes (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35246), but that way lies madness... The file 01CelestialSphere.nb is a Mathematica notebook that shows how to get the star coordinates and format them for OpenSCAD. Future developments As a future development of this project, I want to connect up the stars to show the constellations. This will involve drawing geodesic acs on the surface of the sphere between stars. There is an easy way to do this in OpenSCAD, but I haven't finished working out the maths yet! Another development I am working on is to do a simplified sphere (or even cylinder) that only has the Zodiac constellations. Watch this space (pun intended)!

title: "Old Flo / Draped Seated Woman" by Henry Moore

description.text:
"Draped Seated Woman" by Henry Moore
Scanned at the Yorkshire Sculpture Park, August 2012 I guess i got caught up in the whirlwind of the semester starting and forgot to post this earlier in the year. It is a scan made with 123d Catch of Henry Moore's "Draped Seated Woman." This piece has been sited at the Yorkshire Sculpture Park in the UK, for about as long as I can remember -- and one assumed it would stay there. However the owners of the piece - Tower Hamlets Council - in London are putting it up for sale at Christies Auction House to meet budget shortfalls. Apparently they hope to raise Â£4 - Â£17 million from the sale of the piece. http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/11/08/henry-moore-sculpture-sold-london_n_2091431.html
Print it. Mail it to Tower Hamlets Council.

author: hodo

description.text:
Keep those decks in slick sleeves from sliding all over the table!
Card holder for playing collectable card games. Will fit standard sized cards in sleeves, up to a deck of about 60 cards.
Tested at Friday Night Magic last night, works great. Only one or two people specifically asked about it, though- I guess 3d printers really are starting to become ubiquitous.
I may do an EDH/Commander sized version (100 cards), but feel free to beat me to the punch or add some improvements if you want. There's a lot of deck boxes for sleeved cards on thingiverse, but I didn't find anything that will let you casually dispense them as you play, so I designed one myself.

• Print.
  • Trim or sand (if necessary.)
  • Play.
    • The original version was too fragile, so I added some thickness to the bottom of the ramps and filled in some gaps. ReplicatorG gave me some errors when generating the gcode, but it printed without any issues. Done at 35% infill on a Thing-O-Matic.

Printed toy table and stools for Playmobil sized figures.  
scad source is provided for your own sizing.

For printing take stool_30x30x22.stl and table_60x60x40.stl (need to be printed upside down). I printed the stools and table with a layer height of 0.3 and 0.4mm, respectively, using a 0.4mm nozzle and PLA. Proper cooling is requried for printing the legs, or just print more stools per job to increase the print time per layer.  
Additionally, although that doesn't seem to be so common anymore on thingiverse, I supply the scad file, which is mostly parametric, so you can size your own versions.  
For good slicing, adjust the layer_h parameter, so the profile on top of the table and stools can be sliced correctly.

description.text:
1U to 6U laser ready rack mount fascias. Add your cutouts, and strart making your own rack mounted kit.  
6mm ply or two 3mm sheets is normally stiff enough for fascia plates that don't flex when you use them, though you might want to build up layers if you want fittings to not show on the face.   
The left side has only 2 holes per plate, and the right has all the available mounts, including the optional middle holes. leave the edge areas clear of any fittings as they represent the position of the rack, only the central 450mm is available for equipment.  
The sizes correspond exactly to the 19” rack mount specifications, and have been tested in commercially available racks.

• Cut with laser
  • Bolt into rack

title: Servo Gimbal for the Moebius Action Cam

description.text:
This is a remix from callil's great gimbal for the gopro now for the Moebius Action Cam.
I have used callil's STL files and edited it in SketchUp.
Tested it with my APM quad - and it works.
Let me know, if it worked for you too.

You need
  • Moebius Action Cam: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=51954&aff=645639
  • Quad Copter flight controller like one of these:
    -- KK2.1: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=54299&aff=645639
    -- APM compatible: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=37328&aff=645639
    -- MultiWii Pro: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=26588&aff=645639
  • 9g servos like this one: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=662&aff=645639. Use a digital servo for better performance.
  • A small rubber band
  • Moon Gel (http://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_sacat=0&_from=R40&_nkw=moongel&_sop=15) or similar dampening
    1. Print the STL.
    2. Glue the arms onto the angled pieces
    3. Screw the 9g servos to the angled pieces
    4. Screw the servos to the arms
    5. Put some MoonGel or similiar anti vibration in the camera holder
    6. Put a rubber band over the camera.

comments.text:
Made one, also have vibrations ...
I think the biggest problem with this design comes from the "one side" axis :
each arm of the axis only have one side fixation, the plate where the cam goes is only sustained on one side by one micro servo, which is himself only sustained by another micro-servo. Using, like in this picture, cheap "plastic geared" analog micro servos makes the structure too flexible (holding the "base" where you have the "root" servo, if you move it, it woobles a lot).
comments.author: Ulysse31

comments.text:
One strange point also is that it seems that the camera plate was originally designed to be holded on both sides (two holes, one on each side). but the arm that holds it only goes one way. Too bad since it would also reduce vibrations a bit.
Actually the hole is made to allow to screw in the servo arm on the other side... :-)

simple three-way rope lock, only locks once all three components are slid together. the top and bottom parts are held together using dovetail joints while the third part locks them and itself together. I probably should have made the slanty cube a dovetail as well to prevent it popping up.

to assemble
print using the correct settings for your printer. I used 10% infill and 0.2mm layers. get a ~3cm m3 bolt and screw it first through the loose eyelet, then pass it through the part with the female dovetails, then add a spring and finally screw it into the small slanted cube. make sure that the cube is still within its guide when the spring is fully extended. to lock:
slide together the dovetails, then insert the locking pin from the bottom. you should hear a click as the pin mates. to unlock:
pull on the eyelet connected to the locking pin and remove the pin. the dovetails are now free to slide out.

title: Core XY Idler & Motor Brackets for 2020

description.text:
Upgraded versions of Ichibey's Sakura Cube parts.
  • Motor brackets are now slotted to allow some belt tension adjustment.
  • The idler bracket shaft hole is now positioned better for Core XY.
    • Goes with matching X-ends http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:363034

Print with 2-3 shells and a lot of infill for stiffness. All 2020 mounting holes sized for M4 bolts & washers. You can use M5 if you drill out the 4.5mm holes a bit bigger. Motor brackets:
  • Should be made in ABS unless you have good stepper cooling
  • Suits NEMA 17 steppers (w/ M3 fasteners)
    • Idler brackets:
  • Intended idler bearing shaft is a M5 lag bolt 60mm or longer
  • Designed for these flanged bearings: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBGNOI but larger can be used (up to 15mm flange diameter should fit)
  • Depending on your printer's dimensional accuracy, you may need to drill out the idler shaft holes. On my R2x printing in ABS at 100.0% scale, they are a TIGHT fit to an M5 lag bolt. If you drill them out loose, use a nylock nut or some loctite on the M5 shaft to make sure it can't spin out.

comments.text: If I use 20 teeth for turning and 16 teeth in motor end. will that be a problem
comments.author: jarvis32

comments.text: Yeah, should be fine. The main thing is that you need all the belt runs parallel to the linear rods at the MOVING pulleys. Any belt runs between stationary pulleys (idler or motor) can be any angles you want.
comments.author: jarvis32

description.text:
This bracket replaces the somewhat flimsy stock piece for the Solidoodle 2.  My factory brackets were both cracked and due to the lack of stability, it was causing poor accuracy/repeatability in the y-axis.
The overkill bracket is an even beefier piece.  Both work.  I've got one of each installed right now.

You will most likely need to readjust the y-axis belt tension when you install this bracket.  You may also want to install a longer M3x0.5 button head cap screw because the bracket is thicker than the stock piece.  The stock 8mm long cap screw will work but a 10mm cap screw will ensure full thread engagement in the case.  I rounded off the hex on one of the stock cap screws when I removed it (they used Loctite at the factory), so I needed to make a hardware store trip anyway.

description.text: Made as a birthday gift for our friend who loves air plants!  Small smooth holes have been added to the surface to allow for things to be added.

Printed using an Ultimaker with 0.1mm layers, 0.8mm thick walls at 15 percent infill.  This required a lot of support - increased the angle to something like 60 percent to make sure, also used brim to make sure nothing came off the print bed.  
This was printed using the ColorFabb wood filament.  It was entirely printed at 230 degrees and 50 mm/s (not even slowing for the first layer).  Also set flow to 105% to prevent jams. This resulted in extra strings, but after a half hour with an exacto knife the result was excellent.

description.text:
I'll start off with the fact that I had quite a hard time finding a Name for this thing. It's basically an adapter, which lets you reconfigure the Pins of any 28 Pin DIP-IC (I use it for the Atmega8), in an already existing system. You can put the controller (or whatever thingy you have there) on a breadboard, and plug the System Access Gadget (SAG)into the controllers socket on your circuit board. Then you just wire up the pins, and reconfigure them as you please (ad something, leave something out).
The Second part is basically a comb to keep your cables in line, and I made it a bit bigger so you can label the pins with a CD-Marker. This way you can put pretty long cables on it, without having to trace every single one from the very root when you want to wire up the other end. It helped me a great deal, so I thought I put it up for everyone.
Just in case I'm not the only one who etches his circuits a bit prematurely. If you find it useful, please leave a comment.

I think this should be a fairly uncritical thing to print, only for the last few layers, where it's doing the snap-on arms, you should make sure your printer doesn't print so quickly that they melt and deform. I printed with PLA, 0.2mm Layer height, 3 solid layers and 3 Walls, 25% rectangular infill. Then you just take one of these PCBs for prototyping (see picture) and a row of RM2.54 Pins, and some thin cables (mine are ca. 1mm on the insulation, but I had to make the holes in the print 2.2 to make them fit) The PCB has to be cut down to a 38x18(+0/-1) rectangle, and if you use the same type as me, don't forget to cut the copper in the center because you do not want to link the left and right pins together. Then you cut your wires to length, I recommend 40 - 50cm (mine are 25, and they are a bit short), break your pin arrays to length, and solder:

  • Pins. Important that you do these first, as your cables might get loose again if you solder the pins second.

  • All the wires. I used different colors for every port, and Red/Black for Vcc/GND
    • At this point I would recommend you label the pinholes on both pieces, as long as there are no cables in the way. I only put pin numbers on the small one, the "mask" is large enough to write down port-designations. Then you fiddle the wires through the clip from below (Copper pointing towards the plastic!), and, while pulling them through, you clip the board on. Might take a little effort to get it right. All the cables go through the rounded openings at the sides (see pictures). Then the same for the mask, and once all the wires are through, and you are absolutely sure none are misplaced, I recommend soldering some kind of metal pin to them (I destroyed an IC socket for the nice turned ones, but they are a little short for the old, worn out breadboard I use), and cover the soldered spot with heat-shrink insulation. Viola [sic], you are ready to go!
As a fan of Hearthstone I decided to replicate the Arena Keys granted for winning a certain amount of games. This is the one everyone starts with. In my case, usually the one I finish with.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

Bubbles, the Open Source, 3D printed water pipe. Don't use this to do anything illgeal like smoke illegal things. Also on github: https://github.com/Anon3dENT/bubbles and The Pirate Bay https://thepiratebay.se/torrent/7878499

You need: -3D printed parts -slide -perc -lid -Mason jar, 16 oz capacity -One sachet of Sugru http://Sugru.com/ or something else, I dunno -Hot glue gun, or more Sugru -One length of some tubing, ID 5/16" -you can get different tubing, but you need to change the scad file and make new STLs to print -One glass bowl/slide -with the connecting end about 13mm in diameter -Water Assembly

  • Test fit all the 3D parts together and especially the lid on the jar

  • Roll your Sugru into a long snake about 200mm long

  • Press this snake into the space inside the lid between the threads and the ring. See the pic lid.jpg

  • Screw the Sugru-ed lid onto the mason jar to shape the Sugru into a seal, as seen in lid.jpg

  • Remove the lid, check out the sweet groove. The Sugru needs to set for 24 hours before you can use it

  • Hot glue/Sugru a seal around the bottom parts of the slide holder and the top of the perc and install in the lid.

    These need to be airtight

  • Press fit the tubing on to the smaller slide holder bit. See assembly.jpg

  • Wait 24 hours for the Sugru to set

  • Add water, slide, and bud

  • Enjoy

title: Step Trash Can Lid Hinge Replacement

description.text:
The tabs and pins that the lid of the trash can hinges on snapped off years ago. This is a more elegant solution than my original quick fix (bent wire hanger). I overestimated how far back the pivot points used to be, so a full press of the pedal doesn't let the lid fall shut. I decided that's not a bug but a feature. It's an Umbra step trash can, but I imagine this would be a good starting point even if you have a different brand.  
The pins are 4mm in diameter and 15mm long (the version I printed has 10mm pins, but they just barely made it). The brackets are 15mm wide, extend 15mm back and hang down 25mm. Screw holes are 3mm in diameter and bore centers are 10mm apart.  
UPDATE: The originals broke after about two months. I'm not sure if just printing them again with the longer pegs and on my new printer would've been good enough, so I redesigned them.  
UPDATE: Nylon top hinges last very long, over a year on one set, but now the bottom hinge has weakened to the point of breaking, so I had to replace that.

• Print both files with raft. You could try printing them raftless with the pins vertical, ReplicatorG spit red letters back at me when I tried but you may have better luck.
    • (canhinge2 is designed to be printed raftless)

  • Mark and drill holes for the brackets, fit the pins into the holes in the lid, screw the brackets on.

  • Get out of the habit of opening the lid by hand.

Fun to play with and makes a great party favor. Small parts. Children 5+ might have fun assembling from parts.
See in action making a bubble, a flower
Easily customize the looks by printing your own designs on the transparency film.
Fun to make too. I had to use all my maker arsenal, 1) UP Plus 3D printer, 2) Silhouette Cutter, 3) HP Color Laserjet printer.
Combined different materials: 1) Laser Transparency Film for strips, 2) Wooden Dowels for the stick, 3) Straws for the spacer, 4) Glue for putting things together, and of course 5) ABS Filament for joiners.
Toy stores have them for about $3 in different names like spin stick, spindle spinner, magic bubble wand, etc. Clearly, it is cheaper to buy, but more fun to make.

• (Optional) Print a design on the transparency film.
  • Cut the transparency film using the provided dxf file.
    1. Before taking the film off the cutting mat, apply painters tape on the tip of the stripes. There are some finely cut parts that might get damaged otherwise. (See photos)
    2. The strips have a tendency to get messy. Use a dowel or a craft stick to keep them orderly. (See photos)
  • Print the joiner caps using ABS, 0.15mm layers.
  • Assemble parts
    1. The top cap has a dome and 12 pins. Place a strip on the top cap, aligning the hex cutout with the hex shape of the dome. Push down with the matching cap which has a hollow center and 12 holes around the rim. (Repeat 6 times)
    2. Lock the top cap with the matching cap. Use glue (superglue) to fix the two pieces together. (TODO: get rid of the glue)
    3. The bottom cap has 12 pins, a short hex pipe in the center. One by one, place the open ends of the strips that are previously attached to the top cap onto the hex pipe. Push down with the matching cap after each strip. Make sure the pipe looks away from the top cap, so you can hold it with fingertips when the final assembly is done.
    4. Lock the bottom cap with the matching cap. Use glue (superglue) to fix the two pieces together. (TODO: get rid of the glue)
    5. Cut a 1.5" piece of the straw to work as a spacer.
    6. Pass the wood dowel through the bottom assembly, and then through the spacer before pushing its tip into the top assembly.

author: Blackdog3D

title: Ultra simple inexpensive quick filament spool mount for Mendel Max

description.text: UPDATE: Use the filment guide found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:64302 with this spool holder for the ultimate in Filament Management and Control Nirvana! I searched thingverse for a way to mount a spool on the frame of my Mendel Max MM151 3d printer from https://3dbotic.com but could not find one, so I created this mount. It is very inexpensive to make, very quick to make, and can accomodate different thicknesses of spools.

UPDATE: Use the filment guide found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:64302 with this spool holder for the ultimate in Filament Management and Control Nirvana! The spools I receive when I buy filament have a hole in the center that is about 31.6mm in diameter. 3/4 PVC pipe is about 26.6mm in diameter. PVC pipe slip joint fittings are roughly 33-34mm in diameter (they are not very accurate on the OD). So the pipe will fit into a filament spool, and the fittings on the end will trap the spool so it does not come off. My spools came in 2 different sizes. One was about 90mm wide, and the other was about 60mm wide. You will need to cut the length of the PVC pipe according to the width of your spool, plus some on the ends for the PVC fittings. 1) Obtain 3/4" diameter PVC sprinkler pipe. 3/4 inch is the ID of sprinkler pipe, not the OD, and its a nominal diameter (not actual). Schedule 40 pipe has a thicker wall than schedule 20. Get the Schedule 40 as its stronger. 2) obtain a slip fit coupling, slip fit end cap, and slip fit plug. Make sure that the plug has a relatively flat surface on the end, as this end will butt up againsst the frame 3) you will also need a T-slot nut, and socket head cap screw with a thread that matches yout T-slot nut. In my photo, I am using the Bosch-Rexroth T-slot nut because it can be installed into a T-slot in the aluminum extrusion without taking whatever is on the end of the extrusion off--in other words, this T-slot nut can be install anywhere midway in the slot. This t-slot nut uses a M5 thread, so I am using an M5 x 10mm SHCS and M5 washer. See the photos of the plug. You can see the T-slot nut, and on the inside, you can see the M5 x 10 SHCS. Drill the plug so the screw can go through. 4) cut the length of your 3/4" pvc pipe such that it is long enough to pass all the way through your filament spool, plus has some on each end for the slip-fit coupling, and end cap. See photos. 5) Optional: wrap the PVC pipe in tape where the spool rides on the pipe. I wanted my spool to stay wound on the spool, so a bit of drag on the spool when it rotates is a good idea. The tape increases the friction. 6) Optional (but strongly recommended): download a filament guide that can be attached to the top of your 3d printer. See the first photo I posted for an example. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:64302 Hint:
I made more than one length of PVC pipe when I made the first one, so that I could simply switch out the pipes when I switch spools, and they happen to be different widths. I also made more than one, so I can put 2 spools on my printer frame. Dependin on your spool diameter, and the size of your Mendelmax, you might be able to mount FOUR spools all at once on it! There you have it: a strong, simple, and very inexpensive filament spool mount for your Mendel Max 3d printer! This thing is stronger than a lot of the printed spool holders I looked at on thingiverse (mainly because its not printed), and it took less than 5 min to make, and cost less than $2.00 in parts!

This is a modification of belt tensioner by chopmeister to fit the QU-BD RXL printer belts. I have one each fitted to each Y Axis belt (my X Axis was already OK). On another RXL we fitted this to all three belts.

The issue I had at the time was the wave in prints as the hot-end changed direction. This is a Box to hold the pieces for the 4d-Staunton Full Size Chess Set that i designed. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40605
For all of you that don't want to leave it sitting out all the time. I customize the lid with the name of the person i am giving it to. I put some generic text on the uploaded version. I hope everyone likes it.

This is NOT a small box.
When assembled it will measure 4.5" wide x 8" long x 4.375" deep.
you can control the depth by the number of Middle sections you put in there.
Print with no raft or support.
There are 4 parts to this.
The Bottom "Box 1". (Print one of these)
The Middle "Box 2". ( Print 13 of these)
The Top "Box 3" (Print 1 of these)
And the lid (Print 1 of these)
I tried to print this as a single piece and it is absolutely impossible.
it warps so bad you can't use it.
so it is in 1/4" sections. Very manageable as far as print time and if anything goes wrong you don't waste much plastic.
They do not snap together but they will lock together with locators when you clamp a stack of them together, you will see them when you print.
I will upload pics of how i bonded this together. Clamp it and bond using pure Acetone.
When you are done you will have a very solid great looking box that was 100% printed.

comments.text: Perry, good looking box.  I like the way you kept with the tile theme adding in the honeycomb design.  I used to have terrible warping on long or tall objects but I came across a post somewhere that suggested using a ABS slurry to help adhere the prints to the platform.  I didn't try it for a long time but it sure as hell works.  Just take scraps from the color that you are printing with in abs and dissolve it in acetone.  let it sit for a couple hours and mix.  It doesn't need to be very thick, as long as the liquid takes on the color of the abs it should be fine.  Apply it to your build platform using a q-tip.  It doesn't have to fully coat, in fact it should be applied in a crisscross fashion otherwise your object will be nearly impossible to remove.  I find it works best to apply as the build plate is heating up, around 70 will vaporize off the acetone and leave and nice thin layer of abs for your object to adhere to.  Hope this helps.
comments.author: MikeyB

comments.text:
Thank you for the compliment and the comment Mike!
I read that article you are talking about and it was one of my options at one point. Sticking to my build platform is not my problem, it is the warping of the piece itself. Very large builds will warp so badly that they actually tear themselves apart even when they do not release from the hbp. (they are cooling) I wish i could post pictures in these comments i would show you what i am talking about. I have worked out the adhesion to the table quite well, in fact so well that i have had parts actually lift the Kapton tape off of the hbp when they warp. You can't get it to stick any better than that. I also had to make a special tool for removing my prints because they stick so well. I have destroyed my Kapton tape (and parts) just trying to remove them, even after allowing the hbp to cool to room temp. This is a problem i want! :)
I also have enclosed my Replicator on all sides with clear acrylic panels that are held in place with refrigerator door magnets so there are no breezes inside the machine. The only thing i can think of to fix the warping is to actually heat the entire build environment like an oven, up to between 120c & 140c maybe more, then a controlled cooling cycle. but at that point, our $2,000 machines are getting up to the $10,000 mark. :)
When i was trying to print this box in a single piece it would split itself about every 3/8" at a little over 3" tall i stopped the print and went back to the drawing board. Redesigned it in 1/4" sections and had very little problems after that. They stuck to the hbp just fine but after removing, they are still warped slightly, but after assembly/clamping and acetone bonding they are pretty straight. The lid will be slightly convex but i have found that it helps with a tighter fit and causes no problems.
comments.author: MikeyB

title: Dual E3D v6/ Jhead Hotend Mount V 3.1 | X Carriage for Mendel, Mendel Max,Prusa and co.

description.text: The work on this Thing stopped since i got a different hotend now

After I searched and searched and I havn't found an x carriage for Mendel/Prusa so far, especially not a dual one and after all no E3D one, I decided, tu built my own, and this is where I got.
You can mount two E3D v6 hotends in it (Jhead was reported to work aswell), It got two mounts for the 30mm fans which are delivered with the hot end and two 60 mm fan
.
Please contact me or comment for any modification requests
If you want Custom Models contact me at
[email protected]
.
Changelog:
V4 BOOM - new top file - which now allows leveling and didnt got that nasty clip anymore!! that got quite some work. I think its pretty soon for final built. I can add now v5 versions.
V3.2 The Fanduct mount is now more stable (maybe to stable)
V3.1.1 Added the little Mount for the Belts
V3.1 Some small bugfixes like adjusting the size og the lmuu bearings +0.1mm
V 3 Changed the Model. Now Modular Fan Mounting System for different sizes
v 2.5 Made a new Fanduct which finally works - yay - but still needs some small Improvements
v 2.3 some small changes like holesize of Bearings or air gaps
v 2.2 Added a new fanduct (hopefully working now)
v 2.1 adjusted a mistake in the height of the "Base"
v 2.0 Printed the carriage - IT WORKS :) However it still needs some adjustments
v 1.5 Added my text "DRAGUNARTS" into "base v4.stl"
v 1.4 fixed a hole in "base v3.stl" where the air of the fans got lost
v 1.3 added a fan duct (note that the whole thing is not tested yet)
v 1.2 Released "top v2.stl" because I forgot to cut out the air holes
v 1.1 Added support for sidefans to cool filament while printing
v 1.0 thing released.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

up to 50%

Notes:
  • Dont Print it in PLA (due to the Heat that may soften it)
  • Remove all stringing inside so the Air can flow Flawlessly
  • When Possible takt low infill so the Weight can be reduced

• Print out all parts.
  • Make sure to remove all eventual support Material and ALL strings from inside so the Air can flow without any problems
  • Screw or glue top and base together. If you screw it, screw it with the Fan(s).
  • Place the carriage on the X axis and put the bearings in place.
  • Put in the E3D v6 from the botton to the top. Then take the clip and mount it.
  • Wire everything and have fun
    • Offset between the nozzles: 50mm however. based on your hotend and how accurate the things fit you may have to play around a bit with the value This may help:
  • move your printerhead to the middle of the bed,
  • print out a tiny dot from both nozzles manually with your interface.
  • move your printhead to the homing position.
  • measure the space between the two dots then.
